mr.go.sgfilter
Class SGFilter

java.lang.Object
  mr.go.sgfilter.SGFilter

public class SGFilter
extends java.lang.Object

Savitzky-Golay filter implementation. For more information see http://www.nrbook.com/a/bookcpdf/c14-8.pdf. This implementation, however, does not use FFT

Author:
Marcin Rze≈∫nicki

nl - numer of past data points filter will use
nr - number of future data points filter will use
degree - order of smoothin polynomial
Returns:
Savitzky-Golay coefficients
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if nl < 0 or nr < 0 or nl + nr < degree

smooth

public double[] smooth(double[] data,
                       double[] coeffs)
Smooths data by using Savitzky-Golay filter. This method will use 0 for any element beyond data which will be needed for computation (you may want to use some Preprocessor)

Parameters:
data - data for filter
coeffs - filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - when any array passed as parameter is null

smooth

public double[] smooth(double[] data,
                       double[] leftPad,
                       double[] rightPad,
                       double[] coeffs)
Smooths data by using Savitzky-Golay filter. Smoothing uses leftPad and/or rightPad if you want to augment data on boundaries to achieve smoother results for your purpose. If you do not need this feature you may pass empty arrays (filter will use 0s in this place, so you may want to use appropriate preprocessor)

Parameters:
data - data for filter
leftPad - left padding
rightPad - right padding
coeffs - filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - when any array passed as parameter is null

smooth

public double[] smooth(double[] data,
                       double[] leftPad,
                       double[] rightPad,
                       int bias,
                       double[][] coeffs)
Smooths data by using Savitzky-Golay filter. Smoothing uses leftPad and/or rightPad if you want to augment data on boundaries to achieve smoother results for your purpose. If you do not need this feature you may pass empty arrays (filter will use 0s in this place, so you may want to use appropriate preprocessor). If you want to use different (probably non-symmetrical) filter near both ends of (padded) data, you will be using bias and coeffs. bias essentially means "how many points of pad should be left out when smoothing". Filters taking this condition into consideration are passed in coeffs. coeffs[0] is used for unbiased data (that is, for data[bias]..data[data.length-bias-1]). Its length has to be nr + nl + 1. Filters from range coeffs[coeffs.length - 1] to coeffs[coeffs.length - bias] are used for smoothing first bias points (that is, from data[0] to data[bias]) correspondingly. Filters from range coeffs[1] to coeffs[bias] are used for smoothing last bias points (that is, for data[data.length-bias]..data[data.length-1]). For example, if you use 5 past points and 5 future points for smoothing, but have only 3 meaningful padding points - you would use bias equal to 2 and would pass in coeffs param filters taking 5-5 points (for regular smoothing), 5-4, 5-3 (for rightmost range of data) and 3-5, 4-5 (for leftmost range). If you do not wish to use pads completely for symmetrical filter then you should pass bias = nl = nr

Parameters:
data - data for filter
leftPad - left padding
rightPad - right padding
bias - how many points of pad should be left out when smoothing
coeffs - array of filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when bias < 0 or bias > min(nr, nl)
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - when coeffs has less than 2*bias + 1 elements
java.lang.NullPointerException - when any array passed as parameter is null

smooth

public double[] smooth(double[] data,
                       int from,
                       int to,
                       double[] coeffs)
Runs filter on data from from (including) to to (excluding). Data beyond range spanned by from and to will be used for padding

Parameters:
data - data for filter
from - inedx of the first element of data
to - index of the first element omitted
coeffs - filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if to > data.length
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if from < 0 or to > data.length
java.lang.NullPointerException - if data is null or coeffs is null

smooth

public double[] smooth(double[] data,
                       int from,
                       int to,
                       int bias,
                       double[][] coeffs)
Runs filter on data from from (including) to to (excluding). Data beyond range spanned by from and to will be used for padding. See smooth(double[], double[], double[], int, double[][]) for usage of bias

Parameters:
data - data for filter
from - inedx of the first element of data
to - index of the first element omitted
bias - how many points of pad should be left out when smoothing
coeffs - filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if to > data.length or when coeffs has less than 2*bias + 1 elements
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if from < 0 or to > data.length or from > to or when bias < 0 or bias > min(nr, nl)
java.lang.NullPointerException - if data is null or coeffs is null

public float[] smooth(float[] data,
                      double[] coeffs)
See smooth(double[], double[]). This method converts data to double for computation and then converts it back to float

Parameters:
data - data for filter
coeffs - filter coefficients
Returns:
filtered data
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - when any array passed as parameter is null
